article:
Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel (1770–1831) was a German philosopher and one of the most important figures in German Idealism. His philosophical system is a comprehensive and systematic framework that encompasses various aspects of reality, including logic, metaphysics, epistemology, philosophy of nature, philosophy of spirit, and aesthetics. Hegel's ideas have had a profound impact on modern philosophy, influencing thinkers such as Karl Marx, Friedrich Nietzsche, and Martin Heidegger, among many others.

#Life

##Formative years

###Stuttgart, Tübingen, Berne, Frankfurt (1770–1800)

Hegel was born on August 27, 1770, in Stuttgart, Württemberg (now part of Germany). His father, Georg Ludwig Hegel, was a secretary to the Duke of Württemberg, and his mother, Maria Magdalena Louisa Fromm, was a homemaker. Hegel's early education took place at the Stuttgart Gymnasium, where he excelled in his studies. In 1788, he began his theological studies at the University of Tübingen, where he met his lifelong friends and fellow philosophers, Friedrich Wilhelm Joseph Schelling and Friedrich Hölderlin.

After completing his studies in 1793, Hegel worked as a tutor in Berne, Switzerland, and later in Frankfurt, Germany. During this period, he developed his interest in philosophy and politics, particularly in the ideas of the French Enlightenment and the French Revolution.

##Career years

###Jena, Bamberg, Nuremberg (1801–1816)

In 1801, Hegel began his academic career as a lecturer at the University of Jena, where he taught philosophy and developed his ideas on metaphysics and epistemology. During this period, he wrote his first major philosophical work, "The Phenomenology of Spirit" (1807), which explores the development of consciousness and the nature of reality.

In 1807, Hegel moved to Bamberg, where he worked as the editor of a newspaper. However, he soon returned to academia, becoming the rector of the Aegidiengymnasium in Nuremberg, a position he held from 1808 to 1816.

###Heidelberg, Berlin (1816–1831)

In 1816, Hegel became a professor of philosophy at the University of Heidelberg, where he taught until 1818. He then moved to the University of Berlin, where he became a professor of philosophy and remained until his death in 1831. During this period, he wrote several major works, including "The Science of Logic" (1812–1816) and "The Philosophy of Right" (1820).

#Influences

Hegel's philosophical system was influenced by various thinkers, including Immanuel Kant, Johann Gottlieb Fichte, and Friedrich Wilhelm Joseph Schelling. He was also influenced by the ideas of the French Enlightenment and the French Revolution, as well as by the philosophical and literary movements of his time, such as Romanticism and German Idealism.

#The Phenomenology of Spirit

"The Phenomenology of Spirit" (1807) is one of Hegel's most important works, in which he explores the development of consciousness and the nature of reality. The book is divided into several sections, each of which examines a different stage in the development of consciousness, from the most basic forms of sensory awareness to the highest forms of philosophical understanding.

The book begins with the "Introduction," in which Hegel sets out the main themes and goals of the work. He then proceeds to examine the various stages of consciousness, including "Consciousness," "Self-Consciousness," "Reason," and "Spirit." Each section builds upon the previous one, as Hegel examines the contradictions and limitations of each stage of consciousness and shows how they are overcome by the next stage.

The "Phenomenology" is a rich and complex work that explores many of the key themes of Hegel's philosophy, including the nature of reality, the role of consciousness, and the importance of history and culture. It is considered one of the most important philosophical works of the modern era.

#Philosophical system

Hegel's philosophical system is a comprehensive and systematic framework that encompasses various aspects of reality, including logic, metaphysics, epistemology, philosophy of nature, philosophy of spirit, and aesthetics.

##Science of Logic

"The Science of Logic" (1812–1816) is one of Hegel's most important works, in which he sets out his views on logic and metaphysics. The book is divided into three main sections: "The Doctrine of Being," "The Doctrine of Essence," and "The Doctrine of the Notion."

In the "Doctrine of Being," Hegel examines the basic categories of being, such as quality, quantity, and measure. He shows how these categories are related to each other and how they are necessary for understanding the world.

In the "Doctrine of Essence," Hegel examines the nature of essence and how it relates to being. He shows how essence is the underlying reality that underlies all things and how it is necessary for understanding the world.

In the "Doctrine of the Notion," Hegel examines the nature of the notion and how it relates to being and essence. He shows how the notion is the highest level of understanding and how it is necessary for understanding the world.

##Philosophy of the real

Hegel's philosophy of the real is concerned with the nature of reality and how it is understood. He argues that reality is not just a collection of individual things, but rather a complex and interconnected whole.

##The Philosophy of Nature

"The Philosophy of Nature" (1830) is one of Hegel's most important works, in which he sets out his views on the natural world. The book is divided into three main sections: "Mechanics," "Physics," and "Organics."

In the "Mechanics," Hegel examines the basic laws of motion and how they govern the natural world. He shows how these laws are necessary for understanding the world and how they are related to each other.

In the "Physics," Hegel examines the nature of physical reality and how it is understood. He shows how physical reality is governed by laws and how these laws are necessary for understanding the world.

In the "Organics," Hegel examines the nature of living things and how they are understood. He shows how living things are governed by laws and how these laws are necessary for understanding the world.

##The Philosophy of Spirit

"The Philosophy of Spirit" (1830) is one of Hegel's most important works, in which he sets out his views on the nature of spirit and how it is understood. The book is divided into three main sections: "Subjective Spirit," "Objective Spirit," and "Absolute Spirit."

###Subjective spirit

In the "Subjective Spirit," Hegel examines the nature of the individual and how it is understood. He shows how the individual is a complex and interconnected whole and how it is necessary for understanding the world.

###Objective spirit

In the "Objective Spirit," Hegel examines the nature of society and how it is understood. He shows how society is a complex and interconnected whole and how it is necessary for understanding the world.

###Absolute spirit

In the "Absolute Spirit," Hegel examines the nature of absolute reality and how it is understood. He shows how absolute reality is the highest level of understanding and how it is necessary for understanding the world.

#Philosophy of art

Hegel's philosophy of art is concerned with the nature of art and how it is understood. He argues that art is a form of expression that is necessary for understanding the world.

#Christianity

Hegel's views on Christianity are complex and multifaceted. He argues that Christianity is a form of expression that is necessary for understanding the world, but he also criticizes certain aspects of Christianity.

##Early Romantic writings

In his early Romantic writings, Hegel expresses a strong critique of Christianity and its role in society. He argues that Christianity has become a form of oppressive dogma that stifles individual freedom and creativity.

##The Phenomenology of Spirit

In "The Phenomenology of Spirit," Hegel examines the role of Christianity in the development of consciousness. He shows how Christianity is a form of expression that is necessary for understanding the world, but he also criticizes certain aspects of Christianity.

##The Berlin lectures

In his Berlin lectures, Hegel expresses a more nuanced view of Christianity. He argues that Christianity is a form of expression that is necessary for understanding the world, but he also emphasizes the importance of individual freedom and creativity.

##Issues of interpretation

Hegel's views on Christianity are subject to interpretation, and there is ongoing debate among scholars about the nature of his views.

#Philosophy of history

Hegel's philosophy of history is concerned with the nature of history and how it is understood. He argues that history is a rational and necessary process that is driven by the development of consciousness.

#Dialectics, speculation, idealism

Hegel's philosophical system is characterized by dialectics, speculation, and idealism.

##Thesis–antithesis–synthesis

Hegel's dialectical method is based on the idea of thesis, antithesis, and synthesis. He argues that each stage of development is the result of a dialectical process in which a thesis is opposed by an antithesis, and the two are then synthesized into a higher level of understanding.

#Reception

Hegel's philosophical system has had a profound impact on modern philosophy.

##"Right" vs. "Left" Hegelianism

After Hegel's death, his followers divided into two main groups: the "Right" Hegelians and the "Left" Hegelians. The "Right" Hegelians emphasized the conservative and religious aspects of Hegel's philosophy, while the "Left" Hegelians emphasized the radical and revolutionary aspects.

##Reception in France

Hegel's philosophy was received with enthusiasm in France, particularly among the philosophers and writers of the French Revolution.

##American pragmatism

Hegel's philosophy also had an impact on American pragmatism, particularly in the work of William James and John Dewey.

Humza Yousaf

Humza Yousaf is a Scottish politician serving as the First Minister of Scotland since March 2023. A member of the Scottish National Party (SNP), he has been the Member of the Scottish Parliament (MSP) for Glasgow Pollok since 2016. Yousaf previously served in the Scottish Government as Cabinet Secretary for Justice and Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Care.

# Early life and education

Humza Haroon Yousaf was born on April 7, 1985, in Glasgow, Scotland, to Pakistani parents. He was raised in a Muslim family and grew up in the Govanhill area of Glasgow. Yousaf was educated at Hollybrook Academy and then Mearns Castle High School. He later graduated from the University of Glasgow with a degree in Politics.

# Early career and political involvement

Before entering politics, Yousaf worked as a parliamentary assistant to Bashir Ahmad, the first Muslim MSP. He later became a researcher for the SNP's Westminster group. Yousaf was involved in various community organizations, including the Scottish Islamic Foundation and the Glasgow-based charity, the Poverty Alliance.

# Early parliamentary career

## Election to Holyrood

Yousaf was first elected to the Scottish Parliament in 2011 as a regional MSP for Glasgow. He was 25 years old at the time, making him one of the youngest MSPs ever elected.

## Junior ministerial career (2012–2018)

In 2012, Yousaf was appointed as Minister for External Affairs and International Development, serving under First Minister Alex Salmond. He later became Minister for Transport and the Islands in 2016, serving under First Minister Nicola Sturgeon.

## Cabinet Secretary for Justice (2018–2021)

In 2018, Yousaf was promoted to Cabinet Secretary for Justice, succeeding Michael Matheson. As Justice Secretary, he oversaw the introduction of several high-profile policies, including the Hate Crime Bill.

### Hate Crime Bill

The Hate Crime Bill was a piece of legislation aimed at strengthening laws against hate crimes in Scotland. The bill was introduced by Yousaf in 2020 and received cross-party support. It created new offenses for stirring up hatred against certain groups, including those based on age, disability, religion, and sexual orientation.

## Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Care (2021–2023)

In 2021, Yousaf was appointed as Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Care, succeeding Jeane Freeman. As Health Secretary, he oversaw the Scottish Government's response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

### COVID-19 pandemic

Yousaf played a key role in the Scottish Government's response to the COVID-19 pandemic. He worked closely with health officials and other government ministers to implement measures aimed at reducing the spread of the virus.

### NHS waiting times

During his tenure as Health Secretary, Yousaf faced criticism over rising NHS waiting times in Scotland. He acknowledged the challenges facing the health service and pledged to take action to reduce waiting times.

## 2023 SNP leadership election

In 2023, Nicola Sturgeon announced her resignation as First Minister and SNP leader. Yousaf stood in the subsequent leadership election, running against Kate Forbes and Ash Regan. He won the election, becoming the new leader of the SNP and First Minister of Scotland.

# First Minister of Scotland

## Domestic policy

As First Minister, Yousaf has focused on several domestic policy areas, including health, education, and justice. He has pledged to take action to address the cost of living crisis and reduce poverty in Scotland.

## Economic policy

Yousaf has outlined plans to boost Scotland's economy, including investing in renewable energy and supporting small businesses. He has also pledged to take action to address the impact of Brexit on Scotland's economy.

## Drugs policy

Yousaf has spoken out about the need to reform Scotland's drugs laws, citing the country's high rate of drug-related deaths. He has pledged to explore alternative approaches to tackling addiction, including decriminalization.

## Education policy

As First Minister, Yousaf has emphasized the importance of education in tackling poverty and inequality. He has pledged to increase funding for schools and support teachers in their work.

## Hate crime policy

Yousaf has continued to prioritize hate crime policy, building on his work as Justice Secretary. He has pledged to take action to tackle online hate and support victims of hate crimes.

## Programme for government

In 2023, Yousaf unveiled his first Programme for Government as First Minister. The document outlined the Scottish Government's priorities for the coming year, including action on the cost of living, health, and education.

## International affairs

### European Union

Yousaf has spoken out about the need for Scotland to maintain close ties with the European Union. He has pledged to explore options for Scotland's future relationship with the EU, including membership.

### Scotland–Pakistan relations

As a Scottish-Pakistani politician, Yousaf has emphasized the importance of strengthening relations between Scotland and Pakistan. He has pledged to build on existing cultural and economic ties between the two countries.

### Ukraine invasion

Yousaf has condemned Russia's invasion of Ukraine and pledged support for the Ukrainian people. He has worked with other European leaders to coordinate a response to the crisis.

### Israel–Hamas war

Yousaf has spoken out about the need for a peaceful resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. He has called for an end to violence and a return to negotiations.

2022 AFL Grand Final

The 2022 AFL Grand Final was the 126th annual Grand Final of the Australian Football League (AFL), staged to determine the premiers for the 2022 AFL season. The match was contested between the Geelong Cats and the Sydney Swans at the Melbourne Cricket Ground (MCG) on September 24, 2022.

# Background

The 2022 AFL season was the 126th season of the Australian Football League, the highest level of senior Australian rules football competition in Australia. The season commenced on March 16, 2022, and concluded with the Grand Final on September 24, 2022. The Geelong Cats, led by coach Chris Scott and captained by Joel Selwood, finished the home-and-away season in first place with 18 wins and four losses, earning the minor premiership. The Sydney Swans, led by coach John Longmire and captained by Callum Mills and Dane Rampe, finished the home-and-away season in third place with 16 wins and six losses.

The Swans responded with goals to Lance Franklin and Tom Papley, but the Cats led by 20 points with five minutes remaining. The Cats held on to win the match by 20 points, 14.11 (95) to 11.9 (75).

article:
James Madison

James Madison (March 16, 1751 – June 28, 1836) was an American statesman, diplomat, and Founding Father who served as the fourth President of the United States from 1809 to 1817. He is often referred to as the "Father of the Constitution" for his role in drafting and promoting the United States Constitution and the Bill of Rights. Madison was a key figure in the development of the country's early government and institutions, and his presidency was marked by the War of 1812 and the growth of American nationalism.

#Early life and education

James Madison was born on March 16, 1751, in Port Conway, Virginia, to Colonel James Madison Sr. and Eleanor Rose Conway Madison. He was the oldest of twelve children, and his family was considered to be part of the planter class. Madison's early education took place at home, where he was tutored by a series of private educators. In 1769, he enrolled at the College of New Jersey (now Princeton University), where he studied for two years and developed a strong interest in politics and philosophy.

After leaving college, Madison returned to Virginia and began to study law. However, he never pursued a career in law, instead turning his attention to politics and public service. In 1774, he was appointed to the Orange County Committee of Safety, which was a local government body that oversaw the administration of the county during the American Revolution.

#American Revolution and Articles of Confederation

Madison played a key role in the American Revolution, serving as a delegate to the Virginia Convention in 1776. He was a strong supporter of independence from Great Britain and helped to draft the Virginia Declaration of Rights, which was an influential document that shaped the course of American history.

In 1780, Madison was appointed to the Continental Congress, where he served for three years. During his time in Congress, he played a key role in shaping the country's early government and institutions. In 1781, he helped to draft the Articles of Confederation, which was the first constitution of the United States.

The Articles of Confederation proved to be inadequate for the needs of the young nation, and Madison was a key figure in the movement to replace them with a new constitution. In 1786, he attended the Annapolis Convention, which was a meeting of state delegates that discussed the need for a stronger central government.

#Ratification of the Constitution

In 1787, Madison attended the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia, where he played a key role in drafting the United States Constitution. He is often referred to as the "Father of the Constitution" for his contributions to the document.

After the Constitution was drafted, Madison returned to Virginia and played a key role in the ratification process. He wrote a series of essays, known as the Federalist Papers, in which he argued in favor of the Constitution and explained its provisions. The Federalist Papers were influential in shaping public opinion and helping to secure ratification of the Constitution.

#Congressman and party leader (1789–1801)

##Election to Congress

In 1789, Madison was elected to the first Congress of the United States, where he served as a representative from Virginia. He quickly emerged as a leader in the new government and played a key role in shaping the country's early institutions.

##Bill of Rights

In 1789, Madison introduced a series of amendments to the Constitution, which became known as the Bill of Rights. The Bill of Rights guaranteed certain fundamental rights and freedoms, such as freedom of speech and the right to a fair trial.

##Founding the Democratic–Republican Party

In the early 1790s, Madison began to emerge as a leader of the Democratic–Republican Party, which was a new party that opposed the policies of the Federalist Party. The Democratic–Republicans were committed to limited government and individual liberties, and they opposed the strong central government advocated by the Federalists.

##Marriage and family

In 1794, Madison married Dolley Payne Todd, a widow with a young son. The couple had no children of their own, but they raised Dolley's son from her previous marriage.

##Adams presidency

In 1796, Madison retired from Congress and returned to Virginia. During the presidency of John Adams, Madison emerged as a strong critic of the Federalist Party and its policies. He opposed the Alien and Sedition Acts, which were a series of laws that restricted civil liberties and silenced opposition to the government.

#Secretary of State (1801–1809)

In 1801, Madison was appointed Secretary of State by President Thomas Jefferson. He served in this position for eight years, during which time he played a key role in shaping the country's foreign policy.

##1808 presidential election

In 1808, Madison was elected as the fourth President of the United States, defeating Charles C. Pinckney of the Federalist Party.

#Presidency (1809–1817)

##Inauguration and cabinet

Madison was inaugurated as President on March 4, 1809. He appointed a cabinet that included Robert Smith as Secretary of State, William Eustis as Secretary of War, and Albert Gallatin as Secretary of the Treasury.

##War of 1812

###Prelude to war

During Madison's presidency, tensions between the United States and Great Britain increased, leading to the outbreak of the War of 1812. The British had imposed a series of trade restrictions and impressment of American sailors, which the United States saw as a threat to its sovereignty.

###Military actions

The War of 1812 was marked by a series of military defeats for the United States, including the burning of Washington, D.C. by British troops. However, the war also saw several American victories, including the Battle of Lake Erie and the Battle of New Orleans.

##Postwar period and decline of the Federalist opposition

After the War of 1812, the Federalist Party declined in influence, and the Democratic–Republican Party emerged as the dominant party in American politics. Madison's presidency was marked by a growing nationalist sentiment, which emphasized the importance of a strong central government and a unified national identity.

##Native American policy

During Madison's presidency, the United States government pursued a policy of expansion and assimilation towards Native American tribes. This policy led to the forced relocation of many Native American tribes and the loss of their land and cultural heritage.

##Election of 1816

In 1816, Madison was re-elected as President, defeating Rufus King of the Federalist Party.

#Post-presidency (1817–1836)

After leaving office in 1817, Madison retired to his home in Virginia, where he lived for the remainder of his life. He remained active in politics and was a vocal critic of the policies of his successor, James Monroe.

##Death

James Madison died on June 28, 1836, at the age of 85. He was buried on his estate, Montpelier, in Orange County, Virginia.

#Political and religious views

##Federalism

Madison was a strong supporter of federalism, which emphasized the importance of a strong central government and a unified national identity. He believed that a strong central government was necessary to protect the rights and interests of the American people.

##Religion

Madison was a member of the Episcopal Church, but he was also a strong supporter of religious freedom and the separation of church and state. He believed that the government should not impose its own religious views on the people, but rather protect the rights of all citizens to practice their own faith.

#Slavery

Madison was a slaveowner throughout his life, but he also opposed the expansion of slavery and supported the gradual emancipation of slaves. He believed that slavery was morally wrong, but he also saw it as a necessary evil in the context of the American economy and society.

#Legacy

James Madison is remembered as one of the most important figures in American history, and his legacy continues to shape the country's politics and institutions. He is often referred to as the "Father of the Constitution" for his role in drafting and promoting the United States Constitution and the Bill of Rights.

Mass. and Cass
================

Mass. and Cass is a nickname for the intersection of Massachusetts Avenue and Cass Boulevard in Boston, Massachusetts. The area has gained notoriety in recent years due to the presence of a large homeless encampment and the accompanying social and public health issues. The situation has raised concerns among local residents, business owners, and government officials, leading to various efforts to address the problem.

Aftermath of Long Island closure
--------------------------------

### Closure of Long Island services

In 2014, the city of Boston closed the Long Island shelter and treatment center, citing safety concerns and the need for repairs. The facility had provided a range of services, including emergency shelter, substance abuse treatment, and mental health support, to hundreds of people. The closure led to a displacement of these individuals, many of whom ended up on the streets.

### Shelter openings at Mass. and Cass

In response to the closure of Long Island, several shelters were opened in the Mass. and Cass area. These shelters provided temporary housing and support services to individuals in need. However, the shelters quickly became overwhelmed, and the area began to attract a large number of people struggling with homelessness, substance abuse, and mental health issues.

Business concerns
-----------------

The presence of the homeless encampment at Mass. and Cass has raised concerns among local business owners. Many have reported a decline in sales and an increase in crime, including theft and vandalism. Some businesses have also expressed concerns about the safety of their employees and customers. The area has become a hub for panhandling, and some individuals have reported being aggressively solicited for money.

Population
------------

The population at Mass. and Cass is diverse and includes individuals from various backgrounds. Many are struggling with substance abuse, particularly opioid addiction. Others are dealing with mental health issues, including depression, anxiety, and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The area has also become a magnet for sex workers and individuals involved in the sex trade.

Efforts to clear out the encampment
-----------------------------------

### Operation Clean Sweep

In 2019, the city of Boston launched Operation Clean Sweep, a multi-agency effort aimed at clearing out the homeless encampment at Mass. and Cass. The operation involved the deployment of police officers, sanitation workers, and social service providers. The goal was to provide support services to individuals in need while also enforcing public health and safety regulations.

### Sheriff's proposal to force treatment of individuals

In 2020, the Suffolk County Sheriff proposed a plan to force individuals struggling with addiction into treatment. The plan, known as the "Section 35" program, would allow law enforcement officers to involuntarily commit individuals to treatment facilities. The proposal sparked controversy, with some arguing that it would infringe upon individual rights and others arguing that it would provide much-needed support to those struggling with addiction.

### Executive order to clear encampment

In 2020, the Mayor of Boston issued an executive order aimed at clearing out the homeless encampment at Mass. and Cass. The order authorized the deployment of police officers and sanitation workers to the area and provided for the establishment of a command center to coordinate efforts.

### Sweep and diversion to low-threshold shelters

In 2020, the city of Boston conducted a sweep of the Mass. and Cass area, diverting individuals to low-threshold shelters. The shelters provided temporary housing and support services to individuals in need, including those struggling with addiction and mental health issues. The goal was to provide a safe and supportive environment for individuals to access services and begin the process of recovery.

Collection of syringes
----------------------

The presence of used syringes has become a major concern in the Mass. and Cass area. The city of Boston has established a program to collect and dispose of used syringes, but many have reported that the program is inadequate. The collection of syringes is a critical public health issue, as it helps to prevent the spread of diseases such as HIV and hepatitis.

Rise in violence
-----------------

The Mass. and Cass area has experienced a rise in violence in recent years. There have been reports of assaults, stabbings, and shootings, many of which have been linked to the homeless encampment. The violence has raised concerns among local residents and business owners, who have called for increased police presence in the area.

Police presence
----------------

### Overtime spending

The Boston Police Department has increased its presence in the Mass. and Cass area, with many officers working overtime to patrol the streets. The increased presence has come at a cost, with the city spending millions of dollars on overtime pay.

### Lack of intervention in violence

Despite the increased police presence, many have reported that officers are not intervening in violent incidents. This has raised concerns among local residents and business owners, who have called for more aggressive policing in the area.

### Command center

The city of Boston has established a command center to coordinate efforts in the Mass. and Cass area. The command center brings together representatives from various city agencies, including the police department, sanitation department, and social service providers. The goal is to provide a coordinated response to the complex issues facing the area.

article:
Anton Webern
================

Anton Webern (1883-1945) was an Austrian composer and conductor, one of the most important figures in the development of atonality and twelve-tone technique. His music, marked by its clarity, precision, and lyricism, has had a profound influence on the course of modern classical music.

Biography
----------

### 1883-1908: Upbringing between late Imperial Vienna and countryside

Webern was born on December 3, 1883, in Vienna, Austria-Hungary, to a family of modest means. His father, Carl von Webern, was a civil servant, and the family moved frequently during Webern's childhood. In 1890, they settled in the village of Preßbaum, near Vienna, where Webern spent much of his youth.

#### Bucolic Heimat

Webern's early life was marked by a deep connection to the natural world. He spent hours exploring the countryside, collecting plants, and observing animals. This love of nature would later influence his music, which often features themes of landscape and the seasons.

#### University

In 1902, Webern enrolled in the University of Vienna, where he studied music history, theory, and composition. His teachers included Anton Bruckner and Arnold Schoenberg, with whom he would later form a close professional and personal relationship.

#### Schoenberg and his circle

Webern quickly became a member of Schoenberg's inner circle, which included other notable composers such as Alban Berg and Alexander Zemlinsky. This group of musicians, known as the "Second Viennese School," would go on to revolutionize the course of modern music.

### 1908-1918: Early adulthood in Austria-Hungary and German Empire

In 1908, Webern completed his studies and began his career as a composer and conductor. He quickly gained a reputation as a talented young musician, and his music was performed by several prominent ensembles.

#### Marriage

In 1911, Webern married Wilhelmine Mörtl, a talented singer who had studied with Schoenberg. The couple had one daughter, Amalie, born in 1913.

#### Early conducting career

Webern's conducting career began in 1911, when he took a position with the Kassel Opera House. He later worked with the Deutsches Theater in Prague and the Vienna State Opera.

#### Psychotherapy

In 1913, Webern began undergoing psychotherapy with Alfred Adler, a prominent Viennese psychologist. This experience would later influence his music, which often explores themes of psychology and the human condition.

#### "Old song" of "lost paradise"

Webern's music from this period is marked by a sense of nostalgia and longing. His songs, in particular, feature themes of love, nature, and the passing of time.

#### World War I

In 1914, Webern was drafted into the Austro-Hungarian Army, where he served as a clerk. He was discharged in 1916 due to health reasons.

#### Austrian defeat and socioeconomic strain

The defeat of Austria-Hungary in World War I led to widespread economic and social upheaval. Webern, like many other artists, struggled to make a living during this period.

### 1918-1933: Rise in Rotes Wien (Interwar Vienna)

In the aftermath of World War I, Vienna experienced a period of cultural and artistic flourishing. Webern, along with other musicians and artists, played a key role in this movement.

#### Society for Private Musical Performances

In 1918, Webern co-founded the Society for Private Musical Performances, a group dedicated to promoting new music. The society's concerts featured works by Webern, Schoenberg, and other avant-garde composers.

#### Mature conducting career

Webern's conducting career flourished during this period, with performances at the Vienna State Opera and other prominent venues.

#### Relative success in a destabilizing society

Webern's music gained a significant following during this period, despite the economic and social turmoil of the time. His music, marked by its clarity and precision, offered a sense of stability and coherence in a chaotic world.

### 1933-1938: Perseverance in Schwarzes Wien (Austrofascist Vienna)

In 1933, the Austrian government, led by Engelbert Dollfuss, began to implement a series of authoritarian measures. Webern, along with other artists, faced increasing censorship and marginalization.

#### Marginalization at home

Webern's music was officially banned in Austria, and he was forced to rely on performances abroad to make a living.

#### Besieged milieu and political confusion

The rise of Nazi Germany and the increasing militarization of Austria created a sense of uncertainty and fear among artists and intellectuals.

#### Visiting conducting career

Webern continued to conduct abroad, with performances in Germany, Switzerland, and other countries.

### 1938-1939: Inner emigration in Nazi Germany

In 1938, Austria was annexed by Nazi Germany. Webern, who had always opposed the Nazi regime, was forced to flee Vienna.

#### Anschluss

Webern's home was confiscated by the Nazis, and he was forced to live in hiding.

#### Kristallnacht and recoil

The Kristallnacht pogrom in November 1938 marked a turning point in Webern's life. He realized that he could no longer remain in Germany and began to make plans to emigrate.

### 1939-1945: Hope and disillusionment during World War II

Webern's hopes for a better future were dashed by the outbreak of World War II. He was forced to flee from country to country, always staying one step ahead of the Nazi authorities.

#### Swiss and Reich prospects

Webern applied for a visa to enter the United States but was rejected. He was forced to rely on the charity of friends and colleagues to survive.

#### Wartime hopes and reality

Webern's music from this period is marked by a sense of disillusionment and despair. His songs, in particular, feature themes of loss and longing.

#### Refuge and death in Mittersill

In 1945, Webern was shot and killed by an American soldier in Mittersill, Austria. He was 61 years old.

Music
------

### 1899-1908: Formative juvenilia and emergence from study

Webern's early music is marked by a sense of experimentation and exploration. He was heavily influenced by the music of Richard Wagner and Anton Bruckner.

### 1908-1914: Atonality and aphorisms

Webern's music from this period is characterized by a move towards atonality and a focus on short, aphoristic forms. His songs, in particular, feature themes of love and nature.

### 1914-1924: Mid-period Lieder

Webern's Lieder from this period are marked by a sense of intimacy and lyricism. His music features complex harmonies and innovative uses of rhythm.

### 1924-1945: Formal coherence and expansion

Webern's music from this period is characterized by a sense of formal coherence and expansion. His symphonies, in particular, feature complex structures and innovative uses of harmony.

### Arrangements and orchestrations

Webern was a skilled arranger and orchestrator, and he produced numerous arrangements of the music of other composers.

Reception, influence, and legacy
---------------------------------

### Performance practice

Webern's music has been performed by numerous ensembles and musicians, including the Vienna Philharmonic and the Berlin Philharmonic.

### Contemporaries

Webern was influenced by a wide range of contemporaries, including Arnold Schoenberg, Alban Berg, and Alexander Zemlinsky.

#### Artists

Webern was also influenced by artists such as Oskar Kokoschka and Egon Schiele.

#### Musicians

Webern's music was performed by numerous musicians, including the pianist Eduard Steuermann and the conductor Hermann Scherchen.

Webern's music experienced a resurgence of interest in the 1940s and 1950s, with numerous performances and recordings.

### 1950s onward: Beyond (late) Webern

Webern's music has continued to influence composers and musicians to the present day. His music has been reinterpreted and recontextualized in numerous ways.

### Eastern Europe

Webern's music was particularly influential in Eastern Europe, where it was seen as a symbol of cultural resistance against the Soviet regime.

#### Eastern Bloc

Webern's music was performed and promoted in numerous Eastern Bloc countries, including Poland and Czechoslovakia.

#### Soviet Russia

Webern's music was also influential in Soviet Russia, where it was seen as a symbol of cultural modernism.

### Dance

Webern's music has been used in numerous dance productions, including ballets and modern dance pieces.

### Since the 1980s: Reappraisals and historiography

Webern's music has undergone a significant reappraisal since the 1980s, with numerous new recordings and performances.

Running Up That Hill

"Running Up That Hill" is a song by English singer-songwriter Kate Bush, released in 1985 as the lead single from her fifth studio album, Hounds of Love. The song was a major commercial success, reaching the top 10 in several countries, including the UK, where it peaked at number 3 on the Singles Chart.

#Music and lyrics

"Running Up That Hill" is a mid-tempo song with a mix of electronic and rock elements. The song features a prominent use of synthesizers and a driving beat, which was a departure from Bush's earlier work. The lyrics of the song are somewhat abstract and open to interpretation, but they appear to describe a sense of desperation and longing. Bush has said that the song was inspired by the idea of "two people who are in a relationship, and they're having difficulties, and they're trying to find a way to make it work."

The song's title is a reference to the idea of "running up a hill" as a metaphor for the difficulties of relationships. Bush has said that she was inspired by the idea of "trying to get to the top of a hill, but it's a very difficult climb." The song's chorus features the repeated phrase "if I only could, I'd make a deal with God," which has been interpreted as a reference to the idea of making a sacrifice in order to save a relationship.

##Composition

The song's composition is notable for its use of a Fairlight CMI synthesizer, which was a cutting-edge instrument at the time of the song's release. The Fairlight was used to create the song's distinctive "cloud" sound, which is heard throughout the track. The song also features a prominent use of drums, which were played by Stuart Elliott.

#Recording

"Running Up That Hill" was recorded at Bush's home studio, which was located in a converted barn on her family's estate in East Sussex. The song was produced by Bush and Del Palmer, who had previously worked with Bush on her 1982 album, The Dreaming.

Cirkus (film)
================

Cirkus is an upcoming Indian Hindi-language comedy-drama film directed by Rohit Shetty and produced by Reliance Entertainment and T-Series Films. The film is set to release on December 23, 2022, and features an ensemble cast, including Ranveer Singh, Varun Sharma, Pooja Hegde, and Jacqueline Fernandez.

Plot
=====

The film is set in the 1960s and follows the story of two sets of identical twins, who were accidentally separated at birth. The twins, played by Ranveer Singh and Varun Sharma, are unaware of each other's existence and lead separate lives. The story takes a turn when they meet and their lives become intertwined, leading to a series of comedic misunderstandings and events.

### Development

The film was announced in October 2020, with Rohit Shetty set to direct and Ranveer Singh and Varun Sharma cast in the lead roles. The film's script was written by Yunus Sajawal, Farhad Samji, and Sanchit Bedre. The story is inspired by the 1982 film Angoor, which was based on William Shakespeare's play The Comedy of Errors.

### Casting

The film features an ensemble cast, with Ranveer Singh and Varun Sharma playing the lead roles of identical twins. Pooja Hegde and Jacqueline Fernandez were cast as the female leads, with Johnny Lever, Sanjay Mishra, and Vrajesh Hirjee playing supporting roles.

### Filming

Principal photography began in November 2020 and took place in various locations, including Mumbai, Ooty, and Goa. The film's cinematography was handled by Jomon T. John, with editing by Bunty Nagi.

### Post-production

The film's post-production work began in February 2022, with the music composed by Pritam. The film's sound design and mixing were handled by Anuj Mathur and Resul Pookutty.

Music
=====

The film's soundtrack was composed by Pritam, with lyrics by Kumaar, Shabbir Ahmed, and Dev Kohli. The soundtrack features five tracks, including the title song "Cirkus", which was released in November 2022.

Release
=======

### Theatrical

The film is set to release on December 23, 2022, in theaters across India. The film's trailer was released on November 28, 2022, and received a positive response from audiences.

### Home media

The film will be available on streaming platforms after its theatrical release. The film's home media rights have been acquired by ZEE5.

Reception

article:
2023 ICC Women's T20 World Cup

The 2023 ICC Women's T20 World Cup was the eighth edition of the ICC Women's T20 World Cup, a biennial international cricket tournament for women's national teams that are part of the International Cricket Council (ICC). The tournament was held in South Africa from 10 to 26 February 2023.

# Teams and qualification

A total of 12 teams participated in the tournament. The top six teams from the 2020 ICC Women's T20 World Cup, plus the hosts, South Africa, qualified automatically for the tournament. The remaining five teams were determined by the results of the 2022 ICC Women's T20 World Cup Qualifier tournament, which was held in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, in September 2022.

The teams that qualified for the tournament were:

* Australia
* Bangladesh
* England
* India
* Ireland
* New Zealand
* Pakistan
* South Africa (hosts)
* Sri Lanka
* United Arab Emirates

article:
Treat Williams
================

Richard Treat Williams is an American actor and children's book author who has appeared on film, stage, and television. With a career spanning over four decades, Williams has established himself as a versatile and accomplished actor, known for his nuanced and compelling performances.

Early life and education
-------------------------

Treat Williams was born on December 1, 1951, in Stamford, Connecticut, to Marian (née Andrews), a dancer, and Richard Norman Williams, a corporate executive. He grew up in Rowayton, Connecticut, and developed an early interest in acting. Williams attended the Franklin D. Roosevelt High School in Hyde Park, New York, and later enrolled at the Franklin & Marshall College in Lancaster, Pennsylvania. However, he dropped out of college to pursue a career in acting.

Career
-------

### 1972–1979: Stage work and film breakthrough

Williams began his acting career in the early 1970s, performing in various stage productions in New York City. He made his Broadway debut in 1973 in the musical "Grease," playing the role of Sonny LaTierri. In 1975, he appeared in the Broadway production of "Fiddler on the Roof," playing the role of Perchik. Williams' breakthrough film role came in 1979 with the release of "Hair," a musical comedy-drama directed by Miloš Forman. He played the lead role of Berger, a hippie and the leader of a group of young people.

### 1980s roles

Throughout the 1980s, Williams appeared in a range of films, including "The Empire Strikes Back" (1980), "Prince of the City" (1981), "Dead Heat" (1988), and "Third Degree Burn" (1989). He also continued to work on stage, appearing in productions such as "The Greeks" (1982) and "The Front Page" (1986).

### 1990s–2006: Film, theatre, and Everwood

In the 1990s, Williams appeared in films such as "Things to Do in Denver When You're Dead" (1995), "The Late Shift" (1996), and "Deep Rising" (1998). He also continued to work on stage, appearing in productions such as "The Changing Room" (1996) and "The Glass Menagerie" (1997). In 2002, Williams began starring in the WB drama series "Everwood," playing the lead role of Dr. Andy Brown. The show ran for four seasons, earning Williams a People's Choice Award nomination.

### 2007–2023: Final years

In the 2000s, Williams appeared in a range of films and television shows, including "Miss Congeniality 2: Armed and Fabulous" (2005), "Brothers & Sisters" (2007), and "White Collar" (2010). He also continued to work on stage, appearing in productions such as "Guys and Dolls" (2009) and "The Lisbon Traviata" (2013).

Accolades
----------

Throughout his career, Williams has received numerous award nominations for his performances. He has been nominated for a Tony Award, a Golden Globe Award, and a Screen Actors Guild Award, among others.

Personal life
-------------

### Addiction issues

In the 1980s, Williams struggled with addiction to cocaine and other substances. He has spoken publicly about his struggles and has used his platform to raise awareness about addiction and recovery.

article:
Bheeshma Parvam

Bheeshma Parvam is a 2022 Indian Malayalam-language action thriller film written and directed by Amal Neerad. The film stars Mammootty, Soubin Shahir, Sreenath Bhasi, and Nadhiya Moidu in lead roles. The movie is a remake of the 2007 South Korean film "A History of Violence".

# Plot

The film tells the story of Michael (Mammootty), a 40-year-old man who lives with his mother (Nadhiya Moidu) and younger brother (Soubin Shahir) in Kochi. Michael is a quiet and introverted person who runs a small antique shop in the city. However, his life takes a dramatic turn when he is forced to confront his violent past.

As the story unfolds, it is revealed that Michael was once a notorious goon in Kochi, known for his brutal tactics. He had fled the city after a violent incident and had been living a peaceful life with his family. However, his past comes back to haunt him when a group of thugs starts terrorizing the city.

Michael is forced to confront his past and take on the thugs, revealing his true identity as a skilled fighter. As the story progresses, Michael's family becomes entangled in the conflict, and they are forced to confront the consequences of his actions.

# Cast

* Mammootty as Michael
* Soubin Shahir as Peter
* Sreenath Bhasi as Paul
* Nadhiya Moidu as Michael's mother
* Lena as Sophia
* Shine Tom Chacko as Ajai
* Farhaan Faasil as Ajas
* Veena Nandhakumar as Ancy
* Dileesh Pothan as Rajan
* Anagha L. K. as Rachel

## Family tree

* Michael (Mammootty)
	+ Mother (Nadhiya Moidu)
	+ Younger brother Peter (Soubin Shahir)
	+ Wife Sophia (Lena)
	+ Son Ajas (Farhaan Faasil)

# Production

## Development

The film was announced in 2020, with Amal Neerad directing and Mammootty starring in the lead role. The film's script was written by Amal Neerad and Devadath Shaji. The film's production was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

## Filming

The film's principal photography began in December 2020 and was completed in March 2021. The film was shot on location in Kochi and surrounding areas. The film's action sequences were choreographed by Sunil Rodriguez.

# Soundtrack

The film's soundtrack was composed by Sushin Shyam. The film's score was composed by Sushin Shyam and Amal Neerad. The film's soundtrack features four songs, including "Parudeysa", "Rudhiram", "Kanneerin", and "Moothonnu".

# Release

## Theatrical

The film was released theatrically on March 3, 2022. The film received a U/A certificate from the Central Board of Film Certification.

## Home media

The film's digital rights were acquired by Amazon Prime Video. The film was released on Amazon Prime Video on April 1, 2022.

# Reception

## Box office

The film opened to positive reviews and performed well at the box office. The film grossed over ₹50 crore in its opening weekend. The film went on to gross over ₹100 crore in its first week.

## Critical response

The film received positive reviews from critics. The film's action sequences and Mammootty's performance were praised by critics. The film's direction and screenplay were also praised.

# In popular culture

The film's action sequences and Mammootty's performance have been widely praised and have become a topic of discussion on social media. The film's dialogue "I am Michael" has become a popular meme among fans.

# Notes

The film's title "Bheeshma Parvam" is a reference to the Indian epic Mahabharata. The film's story is loosely based on the 2007 South Korean film "A History of Violence".

article:
Karthikeya 2
================

Karthikeya 2 is a 2022 Indian Telugu-language supernatural thriller film written and directed by Chandoo Mondeti. The film is a sequel to the 2014 film Karthikeya and stars Nikhil Siddharth, Anupama Parameswaran, and Harsha Chemudu in key roles. The film follows the story of Karthikeya, who is on a mission to unravel the mysteries of the Lord Krishna temple in Dwarka.

Plot
-----

The film begins with Karthikeya (Nikhil Siddharth), a doctor who is on a mission to find the truth behind the mysterious happenings in the Lord Krishna temple in Dwarka. He is joined by his friends, Srinivas (Harsha Chemudu) and Valli (Anupama Parameswaran), a journalist who is researching the temple's history. As they delve deeper into the temple's mysteries, they begin to experience strange and supernatural occurrences.

As Karthikeya tries to unravel the truth, he discovers that the temple is hiding a dark secret. He soon realizes that he is not alone in his quest for the truth and that there are others who are also searching for the same answers. The group faces numerous challenges and obstacles as they try to uncover the truth behind the temple's mysterious happenings.

Cast
-----

* Nikhil Siddharth as Karthikeya
* Anupama Parameswaran as Valli
* Harsha Chemudu as Srinivas
* Srinivasa Reddy as Dhanvanthri
* Viva Harsha as Sadananda
* Adithya Menon as Santanu
* Tulasi as Karthikeya's mother

Production
------------

The film was produced by Abhishek Agarwal under the banner of Abhishek Agarwal Arts. The film's screenplay was written by Chandoo Mondeti, who also directed the film. The film's music was composed by Kaala Bhairava, while the cinematography was handled by Karthik Ghattamaneni.

The film was shot on location in Dwarka, Gujarat, and other locations in India. The film's production team consisted of experienced professionals, including art director Sahi Suresh, editor Satya Giduturi, and stunt choreographer Venkat.

Soundtrack
------------

The film's soundtrack was composed by Kaala Bhairava, who also sang several songs for the film. The soundtrack consists of five songs, including the popular single "Inaya". The soundtrack received positive reviews from music critics, with many praising the composer's innovative and experimental approach to music.

Release
--------

### Theatrical

Karthikeya 2 was released theatrically on August 13, 2022. The film received a wide release in India and was shown in over 1,000 theaters across the country. The film was also released in the United States, the United Kingdom, and other countries.

### Home media

The film was released on home media platforms, including Amazon Prime Video and YouTube, on September 20, 2022. The film's digital rights were acquired by Amazon Prime Video for a reported sum of ₹20 crore.

Reception
----------

### Critical reception

Karthikeya 2 received mixed reviews from film critics. Many praised the film's innovative storyline, cinematography, and music, while others criticized the film's pacing and editing. The film holds a rating of 5.5/10 on IMDB, based on user reviews.

### Box office

Karthikeya 2 was a commercial success at the box office, grossing over ₹100 crore worldwide. The film's success can be attributed to its unique storyline, as well as the popularity of the film's lead actor, Nikhil Siddharth.

Accolades
----------

Karthikeya 2 won several awards, including the Best Film award at the 2022 Telugu Filmfare Awards. The film's director, Chandoo Mondeti, won the Best Director award at the same ceremony.

Future
--------

A third installment in the Karthikeya franchise is reportedly in the works, with Nikhil Siddharth reprising his role as Karthikeya. The film is expected to be released in 2024.

Notes
------

Karthikeya 2 is the first Telugu film to be shot on location in Dwarka, Gujarat. The film's production team consisted of over 100 crew members, including technicians, actors, and other support staff.

----------

article:
2022 NFL Draft

The 2022 NFL Draft was the 87th annual meeting of National Football League (NFL) franchises to select newly eligible players for the 2022 NFL season. The draft took place on April 28-30, 2022, at Caesars Forum in Paradise, Nevada.

# Host City

The 2022 NFL Draft was originally scheduled to take place in Las Vegas, Nevada, but due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the event was moved to a virtual format in 2020 and 2021. The 2022 draft marked the return to an in-person event, with Caesars Forum in Paradise, Nevada, serving as the host venue.

# Player Selections

The 2022 NFL Draft consisted of seven rounds, with a total of 262 players selected. The Jacksonville Jaguars held the first overall pick and selected Travon Walker, a defensive end from the University of Georgia. The draft saw a total of 36 players selected in the first round, with the final pick being made by the Kansas City Chiefs, who selected Trent McDuffie, a cornerback from the University of Washington.

## Round 1

The first round of the draft saw several notable players selected, including Aidan Hutchinson, a defensive end from the University of Michigan, who was selected by the Detroit Lions with the second overall pick. The Houston Texans selected Derek Stingley Jr., a cornerback from Louisiana State University, with the third overall pick. The New York Jets selected Ahmad "Sauce" Gardner, a cornerback from the University of Cincinnati, with the fourth overall pick.

## Rounds 2-7

The second round of the draft saw the selection of several notable players, including Breece Hall, a running back from Iowa State University, who was selected by the New York Jets with the 36th overall pick. The third round saw the selection of several players who are expected to make an immediate impact, including Alec Pierce, a wide receiver from the University of Cincinnati, who was selected by the Indianapolis Colts with the 53rd overall pick.

# Notable Undrafted Players

Several notable players went undrafted in the 2022 NFL Draft, including Carson Strong, a quarterback from the University of Nevada, and Justyn Ross, a wide receiver from Clemson University. These players will have the opportunity to sign with teams as free agents and compete for roster spots.

# Trades

The 2022 NFL Draft saw several trades take place, with teams moving up and down the draft board to select players they coveted. The Philadelphia Eagles traded up to the 13th overall pick to select Jordan Davis, a defensive tackle from the University of Georgia. The Baltimore Ravens traded up to the 25th overall pick to select Tyler Linderbaum, a center from the University of Iowa.

# 2020 Resolution JC-2A Selections

The 2020 Resolution JC-2A, also known as the "COVID-19 Supplemental Draft," allowed teams to select players who were not eligible for the 2020 NFL Draft due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The 2022 NFL Draft saw several players selected who were eligible under this resolution, including Trey McBride, a tight end from Colorado State University, who was selected by the Arizona Cardinals in the second round.

# Notes

The 2022 NFL Draft saw a total of 41 players selected from the Southeastern Conference (SEC), the most of any conference. The University of Georgia had a total of 15 players selected, the most of any college.

# Summary

The 2022 NFL Draft was a highly anticipated event that saw several notable players selected. The draft marked the return to an in-person event, with Caesars Forum in Paradise, Nevada, serving as the host venue.

The 2023 Martyr's Memorial A-Division League was the 45th season of the Martyr's Memorial A-Division League, the top division of Nepalese football. The season began on 1 February 2023 and concluded on 30 April 2023. A total of 14 teams participated in the league, with Machhindra Football Club emerging as the champions.

article:
2022 Singapore Open (badminton)

The 2022 Singapore Open was a badminton tournament that took place at the Singapore Indoor Stadium in Singapore from July 12 to July 17, 2022. The tournament was part of the 2022 BWF World Tour and was classified as a Super 500 event.

# Tournament
## Venue
The 2022 Singapore Open was held at the Singapore Indoor Stadium in Singapore. The stadium has a seating capacity of 12,000 and has hosted numerous international badminton tournaments in the past.

## Point distribution
The 2022 Singapore Open was part of the BWF World Tour, which means that players earned points towards the BWF World Rankings. The point distribution for this tournament was as follows:

* Winner: 9,200 points
* Runner-up: 7,800 points
* Semi-finalist: 6,420 points
* Quarter-finalist: 5,040 points

## Prize pool
The total prize pool for the 2022 Singapore Open was $370,000. The prize money was distributed among the winners of each category as follows:

* Men's singles: $27,750 (winner), $14,025 (runner-up)
* Women's singles: $27,750 (winner), $14,025 (runner-up)
* Men's doubles: $29,250 (winners), $14,025 (runners-up)
* Women's doubles: $29,250 (winners), $14,025 (runners-up)
* Mixed doubles: $29,250 (winners), $14,025 (runners-up)

# Men's singles
## Seeds
The top eight seeds in the men's singles category were:

1. Kento Momota (Japan)
2. Viktor Axelsen (Denmark)
3. Anders Antonsen (Denmark)
4. Chou Tien-chen (Taiwan)
5. Anthony Ginting (Indonesia)
6. Lee Zii Jia (Malaysia)
7. Jonatan Christie (Indonesia)
8. Ng Ka Long (Hong Kong)

## Finals
The men's singles final was played between Viktor Axelsen and Chou Tien-chen. Viktor Axelsen won the match 21-10, 21-6.

## Top half
### Section 1
The top quarter of the men's singles draw featured Kento Momota, Viktor Axelsen, and Jonatan Christie. Viktor Axelsen defeated Kento Momota in the quarter-finals 21-14, 21-16. Jonatan Christie lost to Ng Ka Long in the second round.

### Section 2
The second quarter of the men's singles draw featured Anders Antonsen, Lee Zii Jia, and Anthony Ginting. Lee Zii Jia defeated Anders Antonsen in the quarter-finals 21-17, 21-18. Anthony Ginting lost to Kanta Tsuneyama in the second round.

## Bottom half
### Section 3
The third quarter of the men's singles draw featured Chou Tien-chen, Ng Ka Long, and Kanta Tsuneyama. Chou Tien-chen defeated Ng Ka Long in the quarter-finals 21-17, 21-18. Kanta Tsuneyama lost to Rasmus Gemke in the third round.

### Section 4
The bottom quarter of the men's singles draw featured Viktor Axelsen, Jonatan Christie, and Rasmus Gemke. Viktor Axelsen defeated Rasmus Gemke in the semi-finals 21-14, 21-16.

# Women's singles
## Seeds
The top eight seeds in the women's singles category were:

1. Akane Yamaguchi (Japan)
2. Tai Tzu-ying (Taiwan)
3. Chen Yufei (China)
4. Pusarla V. Sindhu (India)
5. Ratchanok Intanon (Thailand)
6. Carolina Marin (Spain)
7. He Bingjiao (China)
8. An Se-young (South Korea)

## Finals
The women's singles final was played between Pusarla V. Sindhu and Wang Zhiyi. Wang Zhiyi won the match 21-9, 11-21, 21-15.

## Top half
### Section 1
The top quarter of the women's singles draw featured Akane Yamaguchi, Ratchanok Intanon, and He Bingjiao. He Bingjiao defeated Akane Yamaguchi in the quarter-finals 21-19, 21-18. Ratchanok Intanon lost to Sayaka Takahashi in the second round.

### Section 2
The second quarter of the women's singles draw featured Chen Yufei, Carolina Marin, and An Se-young. Chen Yufei defeated An Se-young in the quarter-finals 21-14, 21-19. Carolina Marin lost to Yeo Jia Min in the second round.

## Bottom half
### Section 3
The third quarter of the women's singles draw featured Tai Tzu-ying, Pusarla V. Sindhu, and Yeo Jia Min. Pusarla V. Sindhu defeated Tai Tzu-ying in the quarter-finals 21-13, 21-19. Yeo Jia Min lost to Wang Zhiyi in the third round.

### Section 4
The bottom quarter of the women's singles draw featured Wang Zhiyi, Sayaka Takahashi, and Han Yue. Wang Zhiyi defeated Han Yue in the semi-finals 21-13, 21-19.

The men's doubles final was played between Mohammad Ahsan and Hendra Setiawan and Aaron Chia and Soh Wooi Yik. Mohammad Ahsan and Hendra Setiawan won the match 21-17, 21-17.
